came to where the Buddha was, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, joined his palms in respect, and said to the Buddha:

I only wish that the World-Honored One will have pity and fulfill my aspiration!

The Buddha said:

If there are good sons who uphold it without transgression, by this cause and condition they will attain Buddhahood.
If there are transgressions that are not repented, they will always be in the three evil paths.
At that time, the Buddha spoke various teachings for King Åšuddhodana. After the king heard the Dharma, he bowed at the Buddha's feet and circumambulated the Buddha before leaving.
The Buddha, for this cause and condition, told the bhiká¹£us:

The bhiká¹£us all said:
Yes, we joyfully wish to hear it!
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Violating killing has three types of taking a person's life:
First, doing it oneself;
Second, instructing others;
Third, sending a messenger.
Doing it oneself means taking another's life with one's own body;
Instructing others means telling another person:
'Seize this person, bind them, and take their life.'
He sends a messenger to tell another person:
Do you know so-and-so?
You seize that person, bind them, and take their life.
When the messenger follows the instructions and takes that person's life, the upÄsaka commits an irredeemable offense.
There are three kinds of taking a person's life:
First, using one's own body;
Second, using something not part of one's own body;
Third, using both one's own body and something not part of one's own body.
As for using one's own body, an upÄsaka uses his hand to strike another, or uses his foot or other parts of his body, thinking:
Cause them to die because of this!
If the other person dies because of it, this is an irredeemable offense;ğŸ”½If they do not die immediately but die later because of it, it is also an irredeemable offense;
If they do not die immediately and do not die later because of it, the offense in this case can be repented.
As for using non-internal colors, if a person throws wood, tiles, stones, swords, spears, bows, arrows, white copper, lead, or tin pieces at another person from a distance, thinking:
May they die because of this!
If they die because of it, it is an unforgivable offense;ğŸ”½If they do not die immediately but die later because of it, it is also an unforgivable offense;
If they do not die immediately and do not die later because of it, the offense in this case can be repented.

As for using internal and non-internal colors, if one uses one's hand to hold wood, tiles, stones, swords, spears, bows, arrows, white copper, lead, tin pieces, or wooden pieces to strike another, thinking:
May they die because of this!
If they die because of it, this offense is unforgivable;ğŸ”½If they do not die immediately but die later because of it, it is also an unforgivable offense;
If they do not die immediately and do not die later because of it, the offense in this case can be repented.

Again, there are those who, not using internal colors, not using non-internal colors, and not using internal and non-internal colors, mix various poisons to kill people, either applying them to the eyes, ears, nose, body, or wounds, or putting them in food, bedding, or vehicles, thinking:
'May they die from this!'
If they die from it, they commit an irredeemable offense;ğŸ”½if they do not die immediately but later die from it, they also commit an irredeemable offense;
if they do not die immediately and do not die later, the offense in this case can be repented.

There are also those who create smokeless fire pits to kill others, who kill by crushing, by snares, by traps, by touch, by the vidhara method, by abortion, by pressing the belly, by pushing into fire, water, or pits, by sending to die on the road, up to killing in the womb when the two faculties of body and life are first received. Creating smokeless fire pits to kill means:
If an upasaka knows that someone is coming from this road, he first creates a smokeless fire pit on the road, covers it with sand and soil, and says:

'Because this person is coming from this road, I created this pit.'ğŸ”½If that person dies from this, it is an offense of pÄrÄjika;ğŸ”½if they do not die immediately but die later from this, it is an offense of pÄrÄjika;
if they do not die immediately and do not die later from this, the offense in this case can be repented.
If one makes a smokeless fire pit for humans, and a human dies, it is an unforgivable offense;
If a non-human dies, the offense can be repented in this life;
If an animal dies, the lower offense can be repented.
If one makes a pit for non-humans, and a non-human dies, the offense can be repented in this life;
If a human dies, the offense is lower and can be repented;ğŸ”½If an animal dies, one commits a lower offense that can be repented.
If one makes a pit for animals, and an animal dies, the offense is lower and can be repented;
If a human or non-human falls into it and dies, one commits a lower offense that can be repented.
If an upÄsaka does not make a pit for a specific purpose, but causes anyone who comes to fall into it and die, if a human dies, it is an unforgivable offense;
If a non-human dies, the offense can be repented in this life;
If an animal dies, the lower offense can be repented;
If no one dies, one commits three offenses that can be repented through confession.
This is called killing with a smokeless fire pit!

As for the vidyÄdhara, if an upÄsaka on the twenty-ninth day seeks a whole corpse, summons the ghost, and enchants the corpse to rise, washes it with water, dresses it, and has it hold a knife in its hand, if he thinks in his mind and says with his mouth:
'I do this vidyÄdhara for the sake of so-and-so!'
and then recites the mantra, if the person he wishes to harm dies, he commits an irredeemable offense;
if the other person enters various samÄdhis, or is protected by celestial spirits, or is rescued by a great mantra master, and is not harmed, he commits a reprehensible offense.
This is called the vidyÄdhara killing.

As for the half-vidyÄdhara, if an upÄsaka on the twenty-ninth day makes an iron chariot, and after making the iron chariot, makes an iron man, summons the ghost, and enchants the iron man to rise, washes it with water, dresses it, and has the iron man hold a knife in his hand, if he thinks in his mind and says with his mouth:
'I recite this mantra for the sake of so-and-so!'
if that person dies, he commits an irredeemable offense;
If the other person has entered various samÄdhis, is protected by various celestial spirits, or is saved by a spell master, and does not die, the sin in this case can be repented.
This is called half-vidyÄ killing.

As for cutting off life, on the twenty-ninth day, smear the ground with cow dung, place wine and food in it, light a fire, and then immediately put it in the water. If one thinks in the mind and says with the mouth, recite the mantra, saying:
'Just as the fire is extinguished in the water,
when the fire is extinguished, that life will also be extinguished.'
Again, on the twenty-ninth day, smear the ground with cow dung, place wine and food in it, and draw a likeness of the person one wishes to kill.
After drawing the likeness, immediately erase it, think in the mind and say with the mouth, recite the mantra, saying:ğŸ”½'Just as this likeness is erased, that life will also be erased.
When the likeness is erased, that life will also be extinguished.'

On the twenty-ninth day, they smear the ground with cow dung, place wine and food in it, pierce the corner of a garment with a needle, and immediately pull it out. Mentally reciting and speaking the incantation, they say:
Just as this needle comes out, so does their life come out.
This is called taking life.
If one uses various spells to kill someone, one commits an irreversible offense;
if the person does not die, the offense can be repented.

Furthermore, as for causing an abortion, if one gives a woman who is pregnant a medicine to induce vomiting and diarrhea, or an enema, or pierces her blood vessels, up to giving her medicine to induce tears, thinking:
'By these means, I will cause the woman to die.'
If the woman dies, one commits an irreversible offense;ğŸ”½if she does not die immediately but later dies because of it, one still commits an irreversible offense;
if she does not die immediately and does not die later because of it, the offense can be repented.
If one causes an abortion in order to kill the mother, and the mother dies, it is an offense that cannot be expiated.
If the fetus dies, the offense can be expiated.
If both die, the offense cannot be expiated.
If neither dies, the offense can be expiated.ğŸ”½If one performs an abortion in order to kill the fetus, and the fetus dies, it is an offense that cannot be expiated.
If the fetus does not die, the offense can be expiated.
If the mother dies, the offense can be expiated.
If both die, the offense cannot be expiated.
This is called the method of abortion.
As for pressing the abdomen, it means causing a pregnant woman to do heavy work, or carry heavy objects, making her run in front of a cart, or making her climb steep slopes, thinking:
'I want the woman to die.'ğŸ”½If she dies, it is an offense that cannot be expiated.
If she does not die immediately but dies later due to this, the offense cannot be expiated.
If it is not due to death, the offense can be repented in this case.
If it is for the sake of the fetus, as explained above, this is called killing by pressing the abdomen.
Sending someone to die on the road means knowing that there are hungry and ferocious beasts on the road, sending someone to go to the evil path, thinking like this:
'May they die in that evil path.'
If they die, it is an irredeemable offense;
the rest also commit offenses, the same as explained above.
This is called killing in an evil path.
Up to the mother's womb, when the two faculties of body and life are first obtained, at the kalala stage, with a killing mind, one gives rise to skillful means to cause death.
If they die, it is an irredeemable offense;
the rest commit offenses the same as explained above.
Praising killing has three types:
First, those with evil precepts;
second, those with good precepts;
third, the elderly and sick.

As for those with evil precepts, those who kill cows and sheep, raise chickens and pigs, release falcons to catch fish, hunters who surround rabbits and shoot deer, thieves, butchers, those who curse dragons and guard prisons, if one goes to these people and says:
You people with evil precepts, why do you commit crimes for a long time?
It is better to die early.ğŸ”½If this person dies because of this, the offense is irredeemable;
If the person does not die because of this, the offense in this case can be repented.
If an evil person says:
I do not use the words of this person.
If the person does not die because of this, it is a reprehensible offense.
If one praises this person to death, then repents in the mind, thinking:
Why did I teach this person to die?
Returning, one says:

'You evil people, perhaps because of the conditions of a good friend, you have befriended good people, heard the good Dharma, and been able to contemplate correctly, thus escaping evil and sin. You should not kill yourselves.'
If that person accepts their words and does not die, the sin in this case can be repented.
'A person of good precepts' refers to the four assemblies of the TathÄgata.
If one goes to those of good people and says like this:
'You who uphold good precepts have blessings and virtue.
If you die, you will then receive the blessings of the heavens.
Why not take your own life?'
If that person kills themselves because of this, it is an unforgivable sin;
if they do not kill themselves, the intermediate sin can be repented.
If a person of good precepts thinks like this:
'Why should I kill myself because of others' words?'
If they do not die, this sin can be repented.
If after causing another to die, one feels regret and says:
'I am not right!
Why did I cause this good person to die?'
Go back and tell him:
You, a person of good precepts, should live out your life. Because your merit and virtue increase, you will receive more blessings. Do not take your own life.
If the person does not die because of this, the offense can be atoned for in this case.
As for the sick and elderly, the four elements increase and decrease, and they suffer various afflictions. Go and tell this person:
How can you endure this suffering for a long time? Why don't you take your own life?
If the person dies because of this, the offense cannot be atoned for;
if the person does not die because of this, the offense can be atoned for in this case.
If the sick person thinks:
For what reason should I follow this person's words and take my own life?
If, after speaking to the sick person, one's mind gives rise to regret:
I am not right!
Why did I tell this sick person to kill themselves?
Go back and tell him:
'You sick people, if you obtain good medicine and a good nurse, and eat and drink according to the medicine, your illness can be cured. Do not take your own lives!'
If it is not because of the death, the offense in this case can be repented.
The remaining seven kinds of killing, the offenses and non-offenses are explained the same as the above fire pit.
If a person kills with the thought of a person, this offense cannot be repented.
If a person kills with the thought of a non-person, or has doubt about a person, they all commit an offense that cannot be repented;
If a person kills with the thought of a non-person, or has doubt about a non-person, the offense in this case can be repented.
Moreover, a person had their hands and feet cut off and thrown into a moat. Many women came into the city and heard the crying, so they went to watch and said to each other:
'If there is someone who can give this person medicine to drink, causing them to die at the right time, then they will not suffer for a long time!'
There was a foolish and honest woman who gave her the medicine drink, and she died.
The other women said:
You have committed an offense that cannot be atoned for.
She then told the Buddha.
The Buddha said:
When you gave her the medicine drink and she died, you committed an offense that cannot be atoned for.
If a layperson makes an attempt to kill their mother but kills someone other than their mother, the offense in this case can be atoned for;
if a layperson wants to kill someone other than their mother but ends up killing their mother, this is a grave offense that can be atoned for, but not a heinous crime.
If a layperson makes an attempt to kill a human but ends up killing a non-human, the offense in this case can be atoned for;
if a layperson makes an attempt to kill a non-human but ends up killing a human, they commit a minor offense that can be atoned for.
If a person causes an abortion of a fetus that is an animal, they commit a minor offense that can be atoned for;
if an animal causes an abortion of a human fetus, the offense is an offense that cannot be atoned for.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
If a householder makes an arrangement to kill someone, and the householder dies first, and later someone else dies, this offense is reprehensible.
If a householder wants to kill his parents, and doubts arise:
'Are these my parents?
Or not?
' If he is certain that they are his parents and kills them, this is a grave offense that cannot be expiated.
If a householder has doubts, thinking 'Is this a human or not a human?'
If he is certain in his mind that it is a human and kills it, he commits an offense that cannot be expiated.
If someone captures a thief and wants to kill him, but the thief escapes,
if the authorities or the villagers pursue the thief, and a householder comes along the way, the pursuers ask the householder:
'Have you seen the thief?
' If this householder has ill-will and hatred towards the thief, he says:
'I saw him in such-and-such a place.'
If, because of this, the thief loses his life, this is an offense that cannot be expiated.

If a person is about to kill many thieves, and the thieves manage to escape, and if the authorities or the villagers pursue them, and if a householder happens to encounter them on the way, the pursuers may ask the householder:
'Have you seen the thieves?'
Among the thieves, there may be one whom the householder has a grudge against, and he may say:
'I saw him in such-and-such a place.'
If the person is killed, but it is not the one the householder has a grudge against, the offense is reprehensible.
The rest is as explained above.
If a householder kills someone he thinks is his mother but who is not his mother, the offense is reprehensible but not an immediate offense.
If one jokingly strikes another and the other dies, the offense is reprehensible.
If one kills while insane and does not remember it, there is no offense.
If an upÄsaka uses water or grass and trees that contain insects, he commits an offense;ğŸ”½if he uses them with the thought that they contain insects when they do not, he also commits an offense;
if he uses them with the thought that they do not contain insects when they do, he also commits an offense.
There was a householder who built a new house. He was staying on the roof, and a rafter slipped from his hand and fell on the head of a carpenter, killing him.
The householder became suspicious:
'Is this a crime that can be repented or not?'
He asked the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
'There is no crime.'
On the roof, the rafter fell on the carpenter's head and killed him because there were too few people working on it and it could not be controlled.
The householder became suspicious.
The Buddha said:
'There is no crime.
From today on, be careful when working, do not kill people!'
Another householder was working on the roof of his house. He saw a scorpion in the mud, became frightened, jumped down, and fell on a carpenter, killing him.
The householder became suspicious.
The Buddha said:
'There is no crime.
From today on, be careful when working, do not kill people!'

Another householder, at dusk, entered a dangerous path and encountered a thief. The thief wanted to take him, so he abandoned the thief and ran, falling on top of a weaver below the cliff, and the weaver died.
The householder immediately became suspicious.
The Buddha said:
'There is no offense.'
Another householder pushed a rock down a mountain, and the rock killed someone. He became suspicious.
The Buddha said:
'There is no offense.
If you want to push a rock, you should first shout:
'The rock is falling!'
and let people know.'
Another person had a boil that was not yet ripe. A householder burst it for him, and the person died. He immediately became suspicious.
The Buddha said:
'If a boil is not yet ripe and you burst it, and the person dies, the offense in this case is reprehensible;
if you burst a ripe boil and the person dies, there is no offense.'
A young child was happy and laughing. A householder grabbed him and tickled him, causing him to laugh so hard that he died.
The householder became suspicious.
The Buddha said:
'Because it was done in jest, it does not constitute the offense of killing.
From now on, you should not tickle others to make them laugh.'
Again, a person was sitting, covering himself with his robe.
The layperson called out, saying:
'Get up!'
This person said:
'Do not call out, if I get up I will die.'
He called out again, saying:
'Get up!'
As soon as he got up, he died.
The layperson became doubtful.
The Buddha said:
'It is an offense that can be repented of.'
The Second Precept Against Stealing, Told by the Buddha to the Bhiká¹£us:
UpÄsakas, by using three kinds of methods to take others' heavy objects, commit an offense that cannot be repented of:
First, using the mind;
Second, using the body;
Third, moving from the original place.
Using the mind means giving rise to thoughts and wanting to steal;
Using the body means using one's body parts to take others' things;
Moving from the original place means lifting the objects from their original location and placing them elsewhere.
There are three kinds of taking others' valuable things that constitute an indefensible offense:
First, taking oneself;
Second, instructing others to take;
Third, sending someone to take.
Taking oneself means lifting it with one's own hands and moving it from its original place;
Instructing others to take means if an upÄsaka instructs someone, saying:
'Steal others' things.'
When that person takes it according to their wishes and moves it from its original place;
Sending someone means telling a messenger, saying:
'Do you know the location of that valuable thing?'
They reply:
'I know the location.'
Sending them to steal and take it, when that person takes it according to their instructions and moves it from its original place.
There are five kinds of taking others' valuable things that constitute an indefensible offense:
First, taking by coercion;
Second, taking by contempt;
Third, taking by falsely claiming another's name;
Fourth, taking by force;
Fifth, taking by receiving a deposit.
As for valuable objects, if they are worth five coins or more, the offense is one of immediate pÄrÄjika.

If a layperson knows that someone else has the five precious metals or something resembling the five precious metals, and with a thieving mind selects them but does not move them from their original location, they commit a reprehensible offense.
If they select them and move them from their original location, and their value is worth five coins or more, it is an offense of immediate pÄrÄjika.
As for moving from the original location, if woven goods are on a different rope, it is considered a different location;
if it is leather or clothing, the same color is considered the same location, a different color is considered a different location;
if it is leather or cloth goods, the same color is considered the same location, a different color is considered a different location;

if it is a woolen blanket, a single layer of wool is considered the same location, the same color is considered the same location, a different color is considered a different location - this is called the various locations.

If a layperson carries goods for someone else, and with a thieving mind moves them from the left shoulder to the right shoulder, or from the right hand to the left hand, these parts of the body are considered different locations.

For a cart, it refers to the wheels, axle, yoke, and shafts; for a boat, it refers to the two sides and front and back; for a house, it refers to the beams, rafters, roof beams, and ridgepoles, as well as the four corners and the attic, all of which are called different places.
If one, with a thieving mind, moves an object and places it in these different places, one commits an offense that cannot be confessed.

As for stealing objects in the water, if a person, raft, timber, or other objects are flowing downstream, and a layperson with a thieving mind takes them, they commit an offense that cannot be confessed.

If with a thieving mind one holds onto the wood, causing it to stop and then flow to the front, or if with a thieving mind one submerges it in the water or lifts it out of the water, one commits an offense that cannot be confessed.

Furthermore, if there is a pond belonging to someone, and they raise birds in it, if a layperson with a thieving mind presses them down in the water of the pond, they commit an offense that can be confessed. If they lift them out of the water of the pond, they commit an offense that cannot be confessed.
If someone raises birds and they fly into a wild pond, if with a thieving mind one lifts them out of the water or submerges them in the water, one commits an offense that cannot be confessed.
Moreover, there was a householder whose precious ornaments were on the rooftop. A bird took them away. If one snatches them from the bird with a thieving mind, it is an inexcusable offense.
If one sees a bird flying with a precious object and waits for it with a thieving mind, it is a medium offense that can be expiated.
If one uses the power of spells to make the bird go wherever one wishes, it is an inexcusable offense;
if it goes elsewhere, it is a medium offense that can be expiated.
If there is a wild bird that takes a precious object, and a householder snatches it from the wild bird with a thieving mind, it is a medium offense that can be expiated;
if one waits for the wild bird, it is a minor offense that can be expiated.

Moreover, if a wild bird takes a precious object, and a bird belonging to someone else snatches it from the wild bird, and a householder snatches it from the bird belonging to someone else with a thieving mind, it is an inexcusable offense;
if one waits for the bird, it is a medium offense that can be expiated.
The rest is as explained above.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Moreover, if a bird with precious objects is taken by another bird, and a layperson steals it with a thieving mind and takes it, they commit a curable offense.
If they wait for the bird, they also commit a curable offense.
The rest is the same as above.
If a layperson cheats at dice with a thieving mind and wins five coins, they commit an irredeemable offense.
If a layperson steals relics with a thieving mind, they commit a curable offense;
If they have a respectful mind and think:
'The Buddha is also my teacher.'
If they take them with a pure mind, there is no offense.
If a layperson steals a sutra scroll with a thieving mind, they commit an irredeemable offense, depending on the value of the scroll.
There are two causes and conditions for stealing fields, depriving others of their land:
First, verbal disputes;
Second, making marks.

If a layperson, for the sake of land, says that others have won, or if they make a different appearance and obtain land by overstepping the boundaries, the fine is five coins, and it is an irreversible offense.
There are laypeople who should pay customs duties but do not pay them, up to five coins, it is an irreversible offense.
Again, there are laypeople who come to the customs checkpoint and say to other laypeople:
'Pass this item for me, and I will give you half the tax.
' If they pass it on behalf of someone, and the tax is five coins, it is an irreversible offense.
If a layperson shows people a different route, causing them to lose taxable goods, the fine is five coins, and it is a reprehensible offense that can be expiated.
If there are thieves, dangerous animals, or hunger at the tax checkpoint, and they show a different route to avoid these dangers, it is not an offense.
There are laypeople who conspire with thieves to raid villages and obtain goods to share, with a value of five coins, it is an irreversible offense.
As for stealing animals without feet, such as leeches, water fleas, etc., if people take them and put them in a container, and a layperson takes them from the container, it is a pÄrÄjika offense.
The selection is as above.
As for stealing animals with two feet or three feet, such as humans, geese, ducks, parrots, etc., if these birds are in cages and one steals them with a thieving mind, it is a pÄrÄjika offense;
The rest is as explained above.
Stealing humans is of two kinds:
First, carrying them away;
Second, making an appointment.
If a layperson, with a thieving mind, carries a human on their shoulders, and the human's two feet leave the ground, it is a pÄrÄjika offense;
If they make an appointment to walk together and go beyond two so-called so-steps, it is a pÄrÄjika offense;
The rest is all as explained above.
As for stealing animals with four feet, such as elephants, horses, cows, and sheep,
if people tie them up in one place, and with a thieving mind pull them and go beyond four so-steps, it is a pÄrÄjika offense.
If one lies down in one place and, with a mind to steal, drives it up, and it goes beyond four soursteps, one commits an irreversible offense;
The same applies to many-footed animals.
If, within a wall, a fence, or a barrier, one, with a mind to steal, drives it out and it goes beyond the herd for four soursteps, one commits an irreversible offense;
The rest is as explained above.
If, outside, one is grazing it, and a householder, with a mind to steal, thinks:
When the herder enters the forest and leaves, I will steal it.
The moment of forming this thought, one commits a curable offense.
If one kills it, one commits the same offense as killing. After killing, if the meat is worth more than five coins, one commits an irreversible offense.
There are also seven kinds:
1. Not thinking it is one's own;
2. Not with consent;
3. Not for temporary use;
4. Knowing it has an owner;
5. Not being insane;
6. Not being mentally disturbed;
7. Not having a disease that impairs the mind.
These seven, if one takes heavy objects, commit an irreversible offense;
Taking light objects constitutes a minor offense that can be repented of.
There are also seven kinds:
First, one's own thoughts;
Second, consenting;
Third, temporary use;
Fourth, referring to having no owner;
Fifth, insanity;
Sixth, mental confusion;
Seventh, illness destroying the mind.
These seven kinds of taking objects are not offenses.
There was a householder who planted radishes. Another person came to the garden and said to the householder:
'Give me some radishes.'
The householder asked:
'Do you have a price, or are you asking for free?'
He replied:
'I have no price.'
The householder said:
'If you need radishes, you should bring a price.
If I just give them to you, how can I provide for my meals morning and evening?'
The guest said:
'Are you definitely not going to give them to me?'
The host said:
'How can I give them to you!
The guest then used magic to make the vegetables wither and dry up.
He then had doubts in his mind:
Have I committed an inexcusable offense?
